data.title: Read Retro Gamer Articles from No. 254
data.text:
Play Expo

Last week I went to the Play Expo retro exhibition in Blackpool. While it was only a week ago for me, for you it was possibly significantly longer. I write these articles quite a while before the magazine gets printed. It’s a kind of time travel, whi

The Retrobates

It has got to be Rez. A truly astonishing game with an incredible soundtrack. Expertise: Juggling a gorgeous wife, two beautiful girls and an award-winning magazine, all under one roof! Currently playing: Silent Hill 3 Favourite game of all time: Out

In The Pipeline

It’s hard to believe, but 2024 is just around the corner. While we’re more than happy to live in the past on the magazine, the ever-evolving world of retro gaming means there’s always plenty to look forward to, whether it’s new hardware or new games.

Loading…

Everyone loves an underdog story and few are as memorable in gaming circles as the tale behind Sega’s Dreamcast. After squandering the success it had found with the Mega Drive on the Mega-CD, 32X and Saturn, Sega quickly found itself on the ropes wit

Crash Live! Is A Smash

The recent Crash Live! event was such a success that the next event has already been announced. Crash Live! 2024 is planned for 23 November 2024 and will once again be held at Kenilworth’s Holiday Inn. Feedback for this year’s event has been great du

A Mascot For The Ages

Super Mario Bros Wonder is all a bit good, but… it left me pondering. In short: what’s the deal with Mario? No, that isn’t the first gag of my upcoming stand-up comedy special (please note: I don’t have an upcoming stand-up comedy special). Why is he

Curious Video Game Machines

It’s always nice to see a regular Retro Gamer contributor taking a deep dive into a subject they’re passionate about, and Lewis Packwood has done just that with his new book Curious Video Game Machines. We caught up with him to find out what went int

News May 2007

On 3 May, three-year-old Madeleine McCann went missing from a holiday resort in Praia da Luz, Portugal. Madeleine’s parents had left their three children asleep while dining in a restaurant, and discovered that their daughter was missing after checki

Charts

1 – Tom Clancy’s Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2 (Ubisoft) 2 – Brian Lara International Cricket 2007 (Codemasters) 3 – Crackdown (Microsoft) 4 – Virtua Tennis 3 (Sega) 5 – Def Jam: Icon (EA) 1 – Sonic And The Secret Rings (Sega) 2 – Wii Play (Ninte

This Month In…

“History will always remember Sega’s last massively successful console as playing second fiddle to the SNES, but it still has moments well worth revisiting that aren’t Sonic The Hedgehog.” Calling it down the middle, then? “Assassin’s Creed, we’re ho

Agent X II: The Mad Prof’s Back!

» AMSTRAD CPC » 1987 » MASTERTRONIC I received an Amstrad CPC 464 for my 14th birthday and I absolutely loved it. For some reason it came with two of the special Amsoft bundles so I had a significant amount of games to enjoy (although the less said a

Don’t Wake Me: 25 Years Of The Dreamcast

It’s July of 1998, and a young boy walks into a newsagent. “I do remember a particular article which was in Edge, it was that famous one that says, ‘Sega Is Dead, Long Live Dreamcast,’” recalls Daniel Crocker, cofounder of WAVE Game Studios. “I remem

Master Of The Arena

How did you get started on Dreamarena? I joined the Dreamarena admin team in early 2000. We were one of the teams at Egomaniacs.net, part of Affinity Internet Holdings, who had a contract with Sega Europe to run the Dreamarena user-generated content,

Wildest Dreams

◼ Every GD-ROM has a regular density section, containing a warning about playing the disc in a stereo. Some games, including Sonic Adventure, Shenmue II, Dead Or Alive 2 and Under Defeat, also use the space to store bonus goodies such as desktop wall

Borders Down

How did you get involved with fan translations? It was actually the result of the highly popular, never contentious COVID lockdowns where I was at home a lot more often than I had been before, for better or worse. There was one title in particular, o

It’s Still Thinking

◼ The Dreamcast is as capable with low-resolution 2D graphics as it is with silky smooth 3D, and the beautiful pixel art in Yuan Works’ puzzle game demonstrates that excellently. Despite being the oldest game on this list, copies of Wind And Water: P

Development Dynamo

The DreamPi is a huge factor in the popularity of online Dreamcast games today. How did it come about? One day I was Googling stuff, and I came across people still playing the Dreamcast online and there was the DC-PC service thing that you could set

Subscribe Today And Get Thec64 Mini Worth £59.99*

• One of our most popular gifts ever, TheC64 Mini contains an incredible range of features• Discover a fantastic library of 64 built-in games• Easy to use – just connect to your HDTV, plug in the joystick and off you go! Gone are the days of loading

Community Connections

thedreamcastjunkyard.co.uk ◼ This long-running site is a one-stop shop for all the latest news in the Dreamcast scene, as well as original features, interviews and reviews of new indie games. As well as the main blog, the site produces the DreamPod p

The Story Of The Graphic Adventure Creator

They say everyone has a novel in them – in the mid-Eighties, Hampshire-based Incentive Software believed the same was true of adventure games. In 1985, it launched The Graphic Adventure Creator (GAC), a utility that combined the text creation facilit

CX78 Joypad

» PLATFORM: Atari 7800 » YEAR: 1989 » COST: £14.99 (launch), £100+ (today, boxed), £20+ (today, unboxed) Joysticks had been the primary controllers of choice for Atari consoles ever since the introduction of the 2600 in 1977, but by the late-Eighties

Build Your Own Adventure

“Incentive kindly included a Quickstart file to save time. It’s called QS.ADV, and it’s an excellent set of starter commands, codes and messages that gives you the basics for most adventures. Load it up when you begin, and it will save you a lot of t

Gac Highlights

◼ Having already produced Quilled adventures such as Seabase Delta and Subsunk, author Peter Torrance was soon in his GAC stride, submitting this amusing Western lampoon for Incentive’s Medallion range. Apache Gold offers excellent graphics, a nicely

The Gac Master

◼ Author Charles A Sharp AKA The Dreaming Djinn dominated the commercial adventure market for two years, creating over a dozen adventures for budget-software houses such as Alternative and Top Ten Software. Charles swapped genres throughout this peri

The Bard’s Tale

Do you remember the first adventure game you played? Yes – it was The Sphinx Adventure, a game bundled with my first computer. I received an Acorn Electron for Christmas 1984. What do you love so much about the genre? My teenage imagination was fille

Chip ’N Dale: Rescue Rangers

» NES » 1990 » CAPCOM The march of time rarely gets to me – I’d be in the wrong job if it did – but sometimes, I can’t help but notice that I’m getting older. I’ve been working on Retro Gamer for a decade now, and I was in my mid-20s when I started –

A Tribute To Graftgold

Graftgold began as ST Software, which Steve Turner formed in 1983 before being joined by fellow coder Andrew Braybrook. Their debut titles were the arcade-inspired shoot-’em-ups 3D Space Wars, 3D Seiddab Attack and 3D Lunattack, which Steve developed

The Making Of Spellbound Dizzy

Fingers hovered over the telephone dial for the umpteenth time: 0 – 8 – 9 – 1, they tapped, then 5 – 5 – 5 – 0 – 0 – 3. Within seconds a recording began that regaled callers with a bunch of hints and tips about Spellbound Dizzy, the fifth adventure g

Conversion Capers

◼ If you’re going to play Spellbound on its lead platform, then be sure to try the 128K version rather than the 48K one. The developer made full use of the extra memory with improved graphics and animation. There is also more dialogue, making for a r

Dizzying Decision

◼ When Dizzy fell from a great height in the other games in this series, he’d merely bounce and roll but in Spellbound Dizzy, he would land with a thud and nurse a sore head. In most of the versions, it also meant losing some energy. ◼ Without a rubb

Cheaters Do Prosper

◼ Aside from being tempted to phone the Dizzy helpline (and incur the wrath of whoever was paying the bill), magazines would, as with so many games, frequently print hints and tips and include maps to assist fellow players. But what was arguably even

Games Starring Living Toys

◼ Though most of the games on this list put you in the role of a good toy, in this Commodore 64 platformer you play as Merton the factory maintenance man, rounding up rebellious clockwork contraptions. This game has been largely forgotten despite bei

Ultimate Guide Power Strike

When Japanese developer Compile debuted its latest shooting game in 1988, it hit on themes that almost feel uncomfortably familiar today. The game was Power Strike; a title that did impressive things in pushing its genre forward, while spinning a yar

What’s In A Name?

◼ 1988’s Aleste – aka Power Strike – is just the start of an elaborate, spiralling series of shooters mostly created by Japanese studio Compile. After the success of the actual first Power Strike game, Compile released Aleste Gaiden to the MSX2 in 19

Playtoday

◼ Japanese porting house M2 has long been known for the quality of its work. However, its shmup-focussed ShotTriggers series takes that effort to a new level, with a steady flow of incredibly good ports of famous shmups, each typically coming with nu

Boss Rush

◼ Most of Power Strike’s 17 bosses take the form of large ground installations. Master the first, and the rest will fall. How To Beat Them: You can rely on bullet cancelling a great deal here, so try to brave staying straight in the middle while hold

Compile Classics

◼ Arriving in 1985, Compile’s Final Justice was one of the team’s first console releases, and an early MSX shooting game. It certainly feels primitive compared to the development team’s later works, but there’s a fun game in there that hints at the e

Indiana Jones And The Fate Of Atlantis

» PC » 1992 » LUCASARTS I’ve always enjoyed LucasArts’ adventure games, and Fate Of Atlantis starts off brilliantly, with the famous archaeologist bumbling his way through Barnett College’s archives in search of a small statue. It not only highlights

Ultimate Guide James Pond II Codename Robocod

Remember Thing On A Spring? Chris Sorrell does. The creator of the James Pond trilogy was a Commodore 64 fan growing up, and Gremlin’s distinctive platformer, which was set in a surreal toy factory, would prove to be a huge influence on the second ga

The Latest News From May 2007

Reports emerging from the Game Developers Conference reveal some interesting commentary. Edge noted that the Wii meant Shigeru Miyamoto was finally seeing movement on the ‘Wifeometer’ – “his way of judging how much non-gamers care about his games”, t

Conversion Capers

◼ The original version is a classic Amiga platformer, dripping with character. Technically it’s an excellent showcase for the base Amiga’s graphic and sound capabilities. The full-screen, multi-direction scrolling is smooth and the tunes are top of t

Fish Tales

◼ Released in 1990, initially on the Amiga (pictured), the original game became a surprise hit and introduced the world to a slick new hero. Its appeal is limited if you return to it after playing the sequel, but it’s still pleasing to play and provi

Boss Rush

◼ Sitting atop a spiky platform, this disgruntled bear drops from the top of the screen, trying to crush you beneath its bulk. How To Beat Them: It lands in one of three places, so wait for it to fall then stomp its head. Pull down for double damage

DEVELOPER Q&A

What was your opinion of the original Amiga version of RoboCod? When I first saw it I was blown away, like many others were. It was the closest I’d seen to a console quality title on the Amiga. While working on the A1200 version I had a couple of tri

Panasonic Q

» MANUFACTURER: Panasonic » YEAR: 2001 » COST: ¥39,800 (launch), £900+ (today, boxed), £600+ (today, unboxed) Though the PlayStation 2 was capable of playing DVD movies as standard and the Xbox could play them with an inexpensive add-on, the GameCube

The Making Of Comanche Maximum Overkill

At the beginning of the Nineties, not many people had NovaLogic on their radar. The company, founded by John Garcia in 1985, first converted arcade titles such as Bubble Bobble and Arkanoid to IBM PCs and Apple computers, and created decent games lik

Comanche’s Competition

◼ The sequel to the immensely successful Gunship (1986), Microprose’s Gunship 2000 (1991) was a true simulation at its core. You start the game with a choice of five different helicopters, but as your rank increases, two additional models become avai

Namco Classic Collection Vol 2

» ARCADE » 1996 » NAMCO Imagine the scenario – you caught a glimpse of an interesting game you didn’t recognise in some arcade far from home, but didn’t get the chance to take a proper look at it, never mind play it. If you’re reading this magazine,

What Is A Voxel?

◼ A voxel is a volumetric pixel, ie a three-dimensional pixel. A pixel is a two-dimensional entity that contains a colour and a brightness value. A voxel, on the other hand, has an additional Z-axis – and this three-dimensionality offers significantl

Gamate Games

◼ DEVELOPER: BIT CORP ◼ YEAR: 1993 ◼ Presentation is rarely a key consideration with Gamate games. From frequent localisation errors to poorly animated sprites and music that makes you want to empty a glue gun into your earholes, these are often basi

If You Like This Try…

ARCADE, 1986 ◼ Another side-scrolling shooter with surreal visuals, Fantasy Zone remains a feast for the eyeballs so many years on from its 1986 debut. True, Opa-Opa is no Totoro in popular culture terms, but at least this game’s star is a Sega origi

More Games To Play

◼ DEVELOPER: BIT CORP ◼ YEAR: 1991 ◼ Bit Corp’s Tennis looks almost identical to Nintendo’s Game Boy title, even featuring a Mario-like umpire (the shades fool nobody), but it doesn’t play the same. Lob is replaced with a smash, and there’s no way to

Raph Koster

Raph Koster originally intended to become a writer, but was seduced by the allure of videogames while at university. After he co-created the online RPG LegendMUD, he was snapped up by Origin Systems and became lead designer on the groundbreaking MMOR

Ultimate Ambition

◼ “We wanted to make an alternate reality,” says Raph about his ambitions for Ultima Online. “We were all sci-fi readers, we had all read Snow Crash, and we knew that we were building the next generation of what a MUD could be. We leaned really heavi

Raph’s Picks

◼ Raph co-developed this text-based multi-user dungeon alongside his wife Kristen and Sherry and Rick Delashmit. The premise is ‘the world the way they thought it was’, and the game sees you travelling between time periods where fact is mingled with

Star Wars Sandbox

◼ “People made fun of us in Ultima Online for having crafting,” recalls Raph. “Competitors ran ads that were things like, ‘Do you play games to bake bread, or do you play to crush?’ And the answer was baking bread, it turned out. With Galaxies, it wa

Rygar: The Legendary Adventure

» PLAYSTATION 2 » 2002 » TECMO Back in 2008 Tecmo released Rygar: The Battle Of Argus for Nintendo’s Wii. It was an enhanced remake of Tecmo’s earlier PS2 game, Rygar: The Legendary Adventure and I’ve owned it since release… and completed it once. Re

Atari 2600+

>> The Atari 2600+ is wooing us with its woodgrain front and metal switches this month, but does it live up to the legacy of the original? Over the page, more fun awaits with Berzerk: Recharged, a Jurassic Park collection and the latest Evercade cart

Evercade Multi Game Cartridges

» System: Evercade » Buy it for: £17.99 each » Buy it from: Online, retail We’ve two releases to look at this month, Full Void and Home Computer Heroes Collection 1. Full Void is a big deal for Blaze Entertainment, as it’s the very first time it has

Berzerk: Recharged

» System: Switch (tested), PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series S/X » Buy it for: £8.99 » Buy it from: Online We’ve enjoyed the vast amount of Recharged games and this is another good buy. Although it now features modernised controls like twin-stick s

Quarter Arcades: Space Invaders Part II

» Buy it for: £249.99 » Buy it from: numskull.com As impressed as we are with Numskull’s latest cab it comes with a rather high price tag. Modern production costs mean it’s nearly double the price of previous cabs in the range, which we feel pushes i

Jurassic Park: Classic Games Collection

» System: Switch (version tested), PS4, PS5, Xbox Series X/S, PC » Buy it for: £26.99 » Buy it from: Online This collection comprises seven Jurassic Park games from the NES, SNES, Game Boy and Mega Drive, which are top-down and side-scrolling action

Great Grinding

AFTER LAST MONTH’S ABSENCE DUE TO MAJOR SURGERY, ANDREW IS BACK TO THE GRIND – WITH A MASSIVE UPDATE ON AN IMPORTANT AMIGA FPS THAT IS ALSO COMING TO OTHER 16-BIT FORMATS, MORE PROJECTS FROM ANDY VAISEY (AS FEATURED IN RG252) AND THE PREVIEW

Processing

“My main inspirations are the Front Mission and XCOM series,” says developer Wonder about the incoming Summer Island Battle Tactics. “I’m aiming to create a unique visual experience. It takes place on a tropical island across several locations

Dreamcast Memories

Sega’s last console is now 25 years old and still appears to be in rude health. Tim, Nick and Darran look back at Sega’s last roll of the dice and what it meant to them. DARRAN So what’s your earliest Dreamcast memory? TIM Playing Crazy Taxi on a dem

Bargain Hunt

Sega’s console has risen in price over the last few years. Finding a nice, boxed PAL version is becoming much harder and will set you back £160. You can get a used boxed one for £100, while a loose console can be picked up for £65. While a great cond

Casting The Dreams

For Ben Boyd, his gaming life started with the Atari 2600, but it was his love for Sega that started his love for collecting. “Christmas Day 1991, I received my first Sega system, the mighty Mega Drive,” he tells us. “This is when I started growing u

Meeting My Heroes

They say never meet your heroes, which is convenient, because it’s not something that usually happens. Writing for Retro Gamer since it began in 2004 has given me the opportunity to meet, thank profusely and occasionally get drunk with many of my gam

Remembering The Dreamcast

Playing Sonic Adventure on the Dreamcast kiosk in Toys R Us when I should have been at work! What an amazing machine! Buying it on launch, going home and being amazed at the visuals in Echo The Dolphin… it was like real life! Going to Curry’s to play

Hero Worship

Meeting Shigeru Miyamoto at Virgin Megastore early Noughties, for a signing. Met Crush 40, Mike Pollock and Takashi Iizuka at Summer Of Sonic in London some years back. They were really great people. I interviewed Tekken main man Katsuhiro Harada for

Mail Bag

Dear Retro Gamer, Hearing of the gigantic takeover of Activision by Microsoft is an undoubted game-changer. This could be the best thing to happen to retro gamers in ages, but it could also be the worst. With Activision having such a vast back catalo

Your Say

Wild Metal Country. It’s just a cracking game with some great physics. Headhunter, because it proved it could be on the same level as the PS2. Skies Of Arcadia. Cracking music, and a story that really made me fully appreciate longer stories in games.

Next Month

EVERYTHING YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT CORE DESIGN’S ORIGINAL TOMB RAIDER Asteroids, Robotron: 2084, Diablo II, Silent Scope, David Bishop, Budokan: The Martial Spirit, Brøderbund, Advance Wars: Dual Strike, The Nineties: A Decade Of Incredible Games, Hom
